The Bosnian–Hungarian War was fought between the Kingdom of Bosnia under Tvrtko I of Bosnia and the Kingdom of Hungary from 1387 to 1390, primarily over control of parts of the Dalmatian coast.
Background
By the late 14th century, Bosnia under King Tvrtko I expanded its influence toward Dalmatia, while Hungary sought to assert claims over the same region.
Course of the war
Details are sparse, but historical sources suggest that Bosnia defended and consolidated its coastal holdings, maintaining control against Hungarian pressure.
Aftermath
Bosnia strengthened its strategic position along the Dalmatian coast, while Hungarian influence in the western Balkans was temporarily limited.
